Award.AwardTitle: RAPID: COLLABORATIVE RESEARCH: Resiliency and Vulnerability to COVID-19 in Rural Communities: Health and Socioeconomic Well-Being in the Context of Ethnic Diversity

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration: The coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) global pandemic continue to be a major public health crisis in the U.S. Missing from the academic and policy discussion is the pandemic’s impact on smaller communities. Rural places are still highly susceptible to COVID-19 even in the absence of confirmed cases, as the pandemic may just be taking hold. This makes rural places statistically invisible, creating a false sense of rural immunity. There is an urgent need to understand the health and socioeconomic impacts of COVID-19 in understudied rural communities, especially in meat packing towns. Near real-time data collection is needed to understand the full impact of COVID-19 and the effectiveness of recovery efforts, especially among vulnerable rural populations, e.g. older, poor, disabled, immigrant, or minority residents. This project will survey residents of midwestern small towns to: (1) document the health, socioeconomic, and emotional impacts of the pandemic; (2) identify local needs and effectiveness of local and state responses; and (3) understand how impacts, responses, and needs vary across diverse small towns. Findings from the project will inform governmental policies and programs at several levels, thus advancing the health and well-being of rural people and places. <br/><br/>Rural places are highly susceptible to COVID-19 even in the absence of confirmed cases, making rural places statistically invisible and creating a false sense of rural immunity. And yet social research to date has disproportionately focused upon the urban impact. This project will survey n=11,716 residents across 65 small towns (between 800 and 10,000 people) using an existing longitudinal rural panel from the Iowa Small Towns Project (ISTP). These ISTP communities are uniquely vulnerable to COVID-19 because they are home to large meat packing facilities, potentially exacerbating preexisting racial marginalization and stigma. The principal investigators will establish an advisory panel comprised of diverse stakeholders who will guide the project. A comprehensive survey and community engagement strategy will be used to effectively oversample meat packing workers and minority residents. Health impacts will include individual COVID-19 physical health issues, access to and use of healthcare, perceived prevalence in the community, and impact on local healthcare systems. Emotional impacts will include standard depression and anxiety scales (CESD-10 and GAD-7), access to and use of mental health services, and general concern about the pandemic’s impact on family and community. Economic impacts will include household employment and income loss, change in spending patterns, access to and use of economic security programs, and local economic impacts. Social impacts will measure how social capital, social support, and quality of life have been affected by the pandemic. Access and trust of COVID-19 information sources will be measured, as will adherence to social distancing. Residents will be asked to rate pandemic preparedness and responsiveness of governments, healthcare providers, local businesses, and community organizations. Findings from the project will inform sociological theories related to social capital, social stress, and socio-economic inequality, particularly related to health and minority status. All findings will contribute to larger bodies of literature related to rural sociology, which seeks to understand the social dynamics of rural life in the United States.<br/><br/>This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of our project is to understand the impacts of COVID-19 on rural communities, patterns of resiliency or vulnerability, and responses of people and places to the pandemic. We give special attention to the challenges facing ethnically diverse meat packing towns. We sent multi-language questionnaires to 13,280 housing units across 73 small towns in Iowa in January 2021. A total of 5,229 questionnaires were returned, for an overall response rate (RR2) of 39.4%, with 42.9% for the general sample and 31.0% for persons of color sample.  

Regarding COVID health impacts, we found that nearly 60% were tested for COVID and 25-33% tested positive, with highest positivity among persons of color (POC) and lowest among seniors. Hospitalization rates from COVID were low, mostly 1.5% for whites, 3.0% (2x higher than non-senior whites) for white seniors and whites in poor health, and 7.9% (5x) for POC. Vaccination intentions differed, being highest at 62% for seniors and 47-48% for POC and those poor health, but low at 39% for whites under 65.

COVID mental health impacts differed according to risk. Depression (CESD-10 scale) was far higher than pre-pandemic levels of 6.7%. Those in poor health showed the most signs of depression at 66%, as were POC at 44%. Whites and seniors scored lower, but depression signs were still high at 38%. Anxiety (GAD-7 scale) was also far higher than the 3.1% pre-pandemic level. The most anxious are those in poor health (38%) and POC (30%), but the white rate was half that at 15%, while seniors had the lowest anxiety at 10%.  Many POC have sought mental health services at rates much higher than whites.

Rural people of color suffered major financial and economic impacts from COVID. Rural POC had severe reductions in employment: 48% had hours cut (1.5x higher than non-senior whites), 28% had benefits reduced (3.5x), 26% had pay cuts (1.9x), and 20% were laid off (1.7x).  As a result, rural POC were unable to pay bills: 38% were unable to pay non-housing bills (4.2x), 27% were unable to pay rent (6.8x), and 30% had to use savings to make ends meet (2x). Rural POC also had fallen into debt: 29% took on debt to pay bills (2.2x) and 17% took on medical debt caused by COVID (4.3x).

Overall, the results of the project can be summarized as follows. For rural seniors (whites), COVID-19 had a minimal impact. Many seniors had prior physical and mental health issues, so there was little change during COVID. Seniors likely self-isolated and got the COVID vaccine early, resulted in low COVID  complications. Seniors had few financial concerns because of sizable non-labor retirement income. For rural whites (<65), COVID was experienced as a mental health issue. Depression became a major issue because of reduced socialization among friends, family, and neighbors. Whites were less likely to work in high-risk jobs, were in good physical health, and were generally financially secure. Lack of health and financial impacts were the likely cause of low vaccination rates and skepticism of COVID as a legitimate disease and threat to public health. For the health compromised (whites <65), COVID was a real threat to their physical and mental health. This was the only group whose health significantly worsened during COVID. Isolation and vaccines were not sufficient to prevent COVID complications. Prior vulnerabilities resulted in very high depression and anxiety rates. This group experienced some financial troubles, but non-labor disability income blunted these impacts. Despite limited savings and few means to earn money, most all were covered by insurance, especially Medicaid, reducing medical debt. By contrast, for rural people of color, COVID was a true pandemic that devastated lives and livelihoods. Many POC were connected to the meat packing industry, through work or living in households with workers), placing them at high physical and financial risk. Persons of color were at-risk for COVID due to working conditions and household living arrangements. POC were also more vulnerable because many had limited income and savings, poor English language skills, poorer educations, uncertain legal or work status in the U.S., and many were socially isolated from health and social services provided by the community. POC suffered very high rates of COVID hospitalizations and high medical debt. Many POC were unable to pay rent and had worsening housing situations that put then at risk of being housing insecure. Unlike other rural people, POC experienced job losses and/or major cuts to working hours, wages, and benefits. All of this likely accounted for very high anxiety levels among POC, and many sought mental health services in greater numbers than whites, seniors, or even though in poor health.
